padding: 14px 20px 0px; background-image: none; background-repeat: repeat; background-color: rgb(247, 247, 247);" data-cellinner="cell1" valign="top"><div id="idEditableArea_1480696629541_cell1" data-innereditablearea="cell1" data-maincontent="1" style=""><div style="line-height: 20px;" align="center">Welcome to the March 2019&nbsp;</div><div style="line-height: 20px;" align="center">American Psychology-Law Society (AP-LS) Newsletter.</div><div style="line-height: 20px;" align="center"><br></div><div style="line-height: 20px;" align="center"><img title="" style="width: auto;" alt="" src="mar2019.png" data-wawidth="1" width="560" border="0"><br></div><div style="line-height: 20px;" align="center">&nbsp;<br></div><div style="line-height: 20px;" align="center">Our monthly Newsletter provides information about activities, upcoming events, and resources to connect the psychology-law community.<br></div><div style="line-height: 20px;" align="center">&nbsp;</div><div style="line-height: 20px;" align="center">AP-LS aspires to excel as a valuable, effective, and influential organization advancing the science of psychology-law and the translation of psychology-law knowledge into practice and policy. &nbsp;</div><div style="line-height: 20px;" align="center">&nbsp;</div><div style="line-height: 20px;" align="center"><br></div><div style="line-height: 20px;" align="center"></div><div style="line-height: 20px;" align="center"><table width="100%" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"><tbody><tr><td style="line-height: 1px;" valign="top" align="left"><table width="100%" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"><tbody><tr><td style="line-height: 1px; padding: 14px 11px 10px 8px; background-image: none; background-repeat: repeat;" data-cellinner="cell2" valign="top"><div id="idEditableArea_1480696629541_cell2" data-innereditablearea="cell2" style=""><p style="line-height: 22px;"><font><font style="font-size: 21px;"><strong><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif">APA COUNCIL OF REPRESENTATIVES MEETING UPDATE</font></strong><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif" color="#222222">&nbsp;</font></font></font></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><font style="font-size: 16px;"><font color="#000000"><span><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif">The APA Council of Representatives met in D.C. February 14-17, 2019. APLS/Division 41 is represented by Jason Cantone and Tom Grisso. At the meeting, Jason Cantone was re-appointed to the Council Diversity Working Group, and elected Member-at-Large for the Public Interest Caucus. Among items on the agenda, Council approved the:</font></span><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif"><br><br><span>·</span> <em>Resolution on Campus Sexual Assault</em><span>,</span><br><span>·</span> <em>Clinical Practice Guideline for the Treatment of Depression Across Three Age Cohorts</em><span>,</span><br><span>·</span> <em>Resolution on Physical Discipline of Children by Parents</em><span>, after some concerns were expressed about whether the resolution’s claim that science supports that spanking leads to negative outcomes has actually been shown, and concern that the resolution would result in disparities for certain racial, ethnic or cultural communities more likely to use spanking,</span><br><span>· 2019</span> <em>Children and Adolescent Mental and Behavioral Health Resolution</em> <span>(rescinding the now out-of-date 2004 resolution on the same topic),</span><br><span>·</span> <em>Revised Model Education and Training Program in Psychopharmacology for Prescriptive Authority</em><span>,</span><br><span>· Creation of a new APA journal,</span> <em>Technology, Mind, and Behavior</em><span>, and</span><br><span>· Proposed change to rules on how Divisions can issue public statements on matters consistent with APA policy, and the information required in APA elections.</span><br><br><span>Last year, Council passed a “transparency” rule to provide for representatives’ individual votes to be made available on the APA website, if 2/3 of Council voted to do so at the beginning of each meeting. Although both APLS representatives voted in support, only 58% of Council supported the motion and it did not pass.</span><br><span>&nbsp;</span><br><span>Following passionate discussion on the Council members’ LISTSERV, there was an information session regarding the ethical, moral, and legal issues surrounding APA accrediting graduate psychology programs at schools that discriminate against minority (generally, on the basis of sexual orientation) populations. A New Business Item on this issue was proposed for discussion at future meetings.</span><br><br><span>Council also heard from task forces on (1) the new APA strategic plan, which seeks to create a more unifying framework within APA to more readily advocate for psychology, and (2) master’s program accreditation, which will next work on articulating competencies and accreditation standards for masters-level health services professionals, which will still need to be developed and approved.</span><br><br><span>For more on these issues, please contact APLS Council Rep Jason Cantone at <a href="mailto:jasoncantone@gmail.com">jasoncantone@gmail.com</a>.</span></font>&nbsp;</font></font></p><p style="margin: 0px 0px 10.66px; The HIG research program commissions basic and applied scientific studies and field validation/effectiveness studies to examine current and new approaches to interrogation to develop and refine an effective, non-coercive, science-based model of interrogation, interviewing, and debriefing that is both legally and ethically sound. We fund/commission these basic and applied research projects through a mechanism called the Broad Agency Announcement (BAA).&nbsp;</font></span></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><font color="#000000"><font style="font-size: 16px;"><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif"><br></font><span style="background-color: white; font-family: &quot;Trebuchet MS&quot;, &quot;Lucida Grande&quot;, &quot;Lucida Sans Unicode&quot;, &quot;Lucida Sans&quot;, Tahoma, sans-serif;"><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif">We are currently soliciting new white papers for potential contract funding with a deadline of <strong>March 29, 2019</strong>.</font></span></font></font></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><span style="background-color: white; font-family: &quot;Trebuchet MS&quot;, &quot;Lucida Grande&quot;, &quot;Lucida Sans Unicode&quot;, &quot;Lucida Sans&quot;, Tahoma, sans-serif;"><font style="font-size: 16px;" face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif" color="#000000">For more information, please click <a href="https://www.fbo.gov/spg/DOJ/FBI/PPMS1/15F06718R0006603/listing.html" target="_blank">here</a> and select “Amendment 1” for the current call for papers.</font></span></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><span style="background-color: white; font-family: &quot;Trebuchet MS&quot;, &quot;Lucida Grande&quot;, &quot;Lucida Sans Unicode&quot;, &quot;Lucida Sans&quot;, Tahoma, sans-serif;"><font style="font-size: 16px;" face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif" color="#000000"></font></span> <font style="font-size: 12px;" face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif" color="#222222"><br></font><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif"><br></font></p><p style="line-height: 22px;"><font style="font-size: 16px;" color="#000000"><strong><font style="font-size: 24px;">TEACHING IN PSYCHOLOGY &amp; LAW:</font></strong> <strong><font style="font-size: 24px;">LEARNING FROM A MASTER: LANDMARK CASE LAW WITH ALBERT J. GRUDZINSKAS JR.&nbsp;</font></strong><br></font></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><font style="font-size: 16px;" color="#000000"><font style="font-size: 16px;" face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif" color="#000000">by Brianne K.
